ContentClassification.TableReference: C. D. Rutherford, “A New Annuity Table Complying with the Requirements of the New Canadian Valuation Standard”, Transactions of the Society of Actuaries, Vol. XVIII (1929)
ContentClassification.TableDescription: 1929 Rutherford’s Annuity Table – Male. Basis: Age Nearest Birthday. Minimum Age: 0 Maximum Age: 104
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Table intended to comply with 1927 amendment of Canadian Insurance Act requiring annuity valuation on a table "deduced from the actual mortality experience covering the period 1900-1920 published in 1924 on behalf of the Institute of Actuaries and the Faculty of Actuaries in Scotland, male or female according to the sex of the nominee.” The mortality experience referenced is set out in the book entitled "The Mortality of Annuitants, 1900-1920 ". These rates however were deduced from the ultimate experience (that is, excluding first five policy years). It was felt desirable to return to the original data rather than endeavor to base any tables on the figures already derived. Methodology: In the absence of information as to the true period of selection, a useful compromise was to construct a table on the aggregate basis but excluding the data of the first policy year. (An option of having a one year select period was allowed with duration 1 values of 59% of Ultimate for same attained age). The data for years of duration 1 to 4 are required for the purpose of the table by attained age. As the underlying data was on an age last birthday basis, an interval of six months was accordingly assumed to bring to age nearest birthday basis. Rates graduated by the Whittaker-Henderson B formula, the first time said formula used for standard tables. On examination of the graduated rates, both the male and female curves exhibited a rate of mortality at age 40 which decreases with age for some years before commencing to increase in the normal manner. For the sake of simplicity it was decided to reject the graduated rates. A slight adjustment was also considered advisable at the end of the tables. To make the tables suitable for valuation purposes, an extension backwards to age 20 or earlier is required. English Life Table No. 8 was selected for this purpose since the years of that study, 1910-1912, occupy roughly a central position in regard to the period 1900-1920. It would appear inconsistent for the annuity valuation standard to be based on a higher rate of mortality than was shown by the valuation standard for assurances, namely the CM^(5) table (See SOA Table 457). Thus for females, English Life No. 8 – Female (See SOA Table 2063) was assumed for ages 26 and under, the rate of mortality according to the CM^(5) table was assumed for ages 31 to 36. For males, English Life No. 8 – Male (See SOA Table 2062) was assumed for ages 24 and under. For ages 34 to 49 the rates of mortality were assumed to be the same as those of the C^M(5) table while for age 29 the rate of mortality was taken as the arbitrary value of .00425. The rates for the remaining ages were then completed by third difference osculatory interpolation thus securing a smooth junction for the various portions of the table.
